problems.title: Rotate Array using Reversal Algorithm
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an array of N integers and an integer K. Your task is to rotate the array to the right by K positions using the Reversal Algorithm.

Reversal Algorithm Steps
1. Reverse the entire array
2. Reverse the first K elements
3. Reverse the remaining N-K elements
This achieves rotation in-place without using extra space.

Note: If K > N, use K = K % N.

Time Complexity
All reversal operations take O(N) time. Space Complexity: O(1).

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N
The second line contains N space-separated integers
The third line contains integer K

Output Format
Print the rotated array after K right rotations.

Example
Input:
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
3
Output:
5 6 7 1 2 3 4
Explanation: Reverse full -> [7 6 5 4 3 2 1], reverse first 3 -> [5 6 7 4 3 2 1], reverse rest -> [5 6 7 1 2 3 4]
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 100000
1 ≤ K ≤ 100000
Values may be negative or positive
Expected Time Complexity: O(N)

def rotateArray(arr, n, k):
    # TODO: Implement reversal algorithm for right rotation
    return arr

def solve():
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    k = int(input())
    result = rotateArray(arr, n, k)
    print(*result)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    solve()

problems.title: Minimum Rotations to Make Array Sorted
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an array of N distinct integers. Your task is to find the minimum number of right rotations required to make the array sorted in ascending order.
If it is impossible to make it sorted using any rotation, return -1.

Right Rotation Definition:
One right rotation means moving the last element to the front.
Example: [1, 2, 3, 4] -> [4, 1, 2, 3]

Approach
1. Create a sorted copy of the array.
2. Check if the array is a rotated version of the sorted one.
3. Determine the rotation index where sorted[0] appears in original.
4. Validate if from that index onward, elements match the sorted array.

Time Complexity
Sorting takes O(N log N), validation takes O(N). Total = O(N log N).
Space Complexity = O(N).

Input Format
The first line contains integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated integers.

Output Format
Print the minimum number of right rotations needed to make the array sorted, else print -1.

Example
Input:
5
3 4 5 1 2
Sorted array is [1 2 3 4 5]
Array matches after 3 right rotations
Output: 3
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 100000
All elements are distinct
Expected Time Complexity: O(N log N)

problems.title: Pair Sum using Two Pointer on Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given a sorted array of N integers and a target sum K. Your task is to determine whether there exists a pair of elements whose sum is equal to K using the two-pointer technique.
If such a pair exists, print YES, otherwise print NO.

Two Pointer Approach:
1. Initialize left pointer at 0 and right pointer at N-1
2. Calculate sum = arr[left] + arr[right]
3. If sum == K -> pair found
4. If sum < K -> move left++
5. If sum > K -> move right--

Time Complexity
Since the two-pointer method scans the array once, the time complexity is O(N) and space complexity is O(1).

Input Format
The first line contains integer N
The second line contains N space-separated sorted integers
The third line contains integer K

Output Format
Print YES if a valid pair exists, otherwise NO.

Example
Input:
6
1 2 3 4 5 6
9
Output:
YES
Explanation: Pair (3,6) gives sum 9
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 100000
Values may be negative or positive
Expected Time Complexity: O(N)

problems.title: Count Pair Sum Combinations using Hashing
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an array of N integers and an integer K. Your task is to count the total number of unique index-based pairs (i, j) such that arr[i] + arr[j] = K using a hashing approach.
Index pairs are considered unique, meaning values can repeat.
Output only the count of such valid pairs.

Example: For arr = [1, 5, 7, -1, 5] and K = 6, valid pairs are (1,5), (1,5), (7,-1). Total = 3.

Time Complexity
Using hashing for frequency counts, time complexity is O(N) and space complexity is O(N).

Input Format
The first line contains integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated integers.
The third line contains integer K.

Output Format
Print the count of valid pairs.

Explanation Example
Input:
5
1 5 7 -1 5
6
Output:
3
Reason: Pairs are (1,5), (1,5), (7,-1)
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 100000
Values may be negative or positive
Expected Time Complexity: O(N)

problems.title: Find All Pairs with Absolute Difference
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an array of N integers and an integer K. Your task is to find all distinct pairs (a, b) such that |a - b| = K.
Print each pair in ascending order (a b) where a < b. If no such pairs exist, print -1.
Do not print duplicate pairs.

Example: For arr = [1, 5, 3, 4, 2] and K = 2, valid pairs are (1,3), (3,5), (2,4).

Time Complexity
Using hashing to check required values, the solution runs in O(N) time and O(N) space.

Input Format
The first line contains integer N
The second line contains N space-separated integers
The third line contains integer K

Output Format
Print each pair on a new line in sorted order: a b
If no valid pair exists, print -1.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 100000
Values may be negative or positive
Expected Time Complexity: O(N)
